Weak Legal Enforcement    - Laws exist, but enforcement is inconsistent.  - Many powerful individuals escape justice due to political connections or bribery.    3. Culture of Patronage (Nepotism & Favoritism)    - "Bapakisme" (fatherly leadership) and gotong royong(mutual assistance) can sometimes blur the lines between loyalty and corruption.  - Many politicians and businesspeople maintain networks where favors and kickbacks are expected.    4. Low Wages in Public Sector    - Many civil servants, police, and government officials receive low salaries, making them more susceptible to bribes.    5. Weak Education on Ethics    - Anti-corruption values are not deeply ingrained in the education system.  - Many people see corruption as a way to survive or advance in life.    6. Public Tolerance & Normalization    - Small-scale corruption, such as bribing traffic police or paying for government services under the table, is often seen as normal.  - When the public tolerates corruption, it becomes harder to eradicate. How It Passes Through Generations    1. Role Models â€“ Younger generations see corrupt practices as a "normal" way to get ahead.    2.
